coredata.dc:title: Study of temperature dependence of density, bulk modulus, shear modulus and thermal pressure for mantle minerals
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Physics and Chemistry of Solids

coredata.dc:creator: Kumar Pandey, Rajiv
coredata.dc:description:
The temperature dependence of different parameters i.e. density ρ(T), bulk modulus K
T (T), shear modulus G
T (T) and thermal pressure ΔP th for mantle minerals i.e. X2SiO4 (X=Mg, Fe, Co, Mn) have been studied in high temperature range on the basis of semi-phenomenological isobaric equation of state. The calculated values of these parameters are showing good agreements with experimental value in case of each mantle minerals.

head.ce:title: Study of temperature dependence of density, bulk modulus, shear modulus and thermal pressure for mantle minerals

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Physics, Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College, Ghaziabad, UP 201009, India

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
The temperature dependence of different parameters i.e. density ρ(T), bulk modulus K
T (T), shear modulus G
T (T) and thermal pressure ΔP th for mantle minerals i.e. X2SiO4 (X=Mg, Fe, Co, Mn) have been studied in high temperature range on the basis of semi-phenomenological isobaric equation of state. The calculated values of these parameters are showing good agreements with experimental value in case of each mantle minerals.

ce:section.ce:para: The temperature dependent volume and thermal expansivity data of any kind of materials i.e. ionic crystal, earth's interior material, etc. are required for developing the equation of state and predicting the temperature dependence of different parameter like volume, density, bulk modulus and thermal pressure, etc.

The studies based on the isobaric equation of state (EOS) are of wide importance in area of physics, geophysics and studying the Earth's interior [1–4]. The EOS are applicable to extrapolate and interpolate the data of different parameters and helpful to plan the different kind of experiments in the area of high temperature and high pressure.

The volume thermal expansion is an anharmonic effect [2]. Some of the experimental values of volume thermal expansion α(T) at high temperature have considerable uncertainty. This uncertainty is responsible for error in the calculation of thermodynamical parameter [5,6]. Various efforts [7–16] have been made to develop semi-phenomenological models or EOS for predicting the values of different thermodynamical quantities with the help of thermodynamical relation, assumption and experimental facts.

In the present communication, EOS has been developed on the basis of the fact that the volume thermal expansion is an anharmonic effect that is considered as the coefficient of volume thermal expansion α(T) is quadratic function of temperature (T). The expression for ρ(T) density has been developed and tested for NaCl ionic crystal [16]. In the present paper, we have extended the use of this equation of state for calculation of different thermodynamical parameter and thermal-pressure as function of temperature (T) of mantle materials, i.e. X2SiO4 (X=Mg, Fe, Co, Mn).
The method of analysis is provided in Section 2 while the results are discussed and compared with experimental data [17,18] in Section 3.

The Anderson–Gruneisen parameter δ
T and volume thermal expansion coefficient α(T) are useful thermodynamical quantities for discussion of the anharmonic properties of ionic solid, minerals, etc. δ

Eqs. (5), (7a) and (7b) are used to compute the density, bulk modulus and shear modulus at different temperature.

A well known thermodynamical identity is used to find the temperature dependence of thermal pressure P th(T). The temperature derivative of thermal pressure P th(T) is equal to α(T), K

The value of different thermodynamical parameters, i.e. ρ(T), α(T), K
T (T), G
T (T) and thermal pressure ΔP th (T) as function of temperature (T) are alculated by using above derived equations, To find these parameters, we need the value of C 1 which is estimated by Eq. (4) for different mantle minerals X2SiO4 (X=Mg, Fe, Co, Mn). The computed values of the parameter C 1 for different mantle minerals are listed in Table 1 .

The values of ρ(T), α(T), K
T , G
T and ΔP th(T) as function T for different minerals, i.e. X2SiO4 (X=Mg, Fe, Co, Mn) are calculated and compared with experimental data for these minerals. The calculated values are tabulated in Tables 2–5
along with experimental values with respect to X2SiO4 (X=Mg, Fe, Co and Mn). A good agreement is found in calculated and experimental values of ρ(T), α(T), K(T), G(T) and ΔP th(T) at different temperature for each of minerals [16,17].

The good agreements of calculated and experimental values of α(T), K(T), G(T) and ΔP th(T) support the validity of the assumption used to develop the EOS and other expressions. This semi phenomenological EOS developed on assumption tested for NaCl crystal is applicable for other minerals and materials.

To summarize, the present study highlights and provides a new and simpler method to study temperature ariation of different-thermodynamical parameters for complex solids such as minerals, i.e. X2SiO4(X=Mg, Fe, Co, Mn). So, the developed semi-phenomenological EOS are useful to thermodynamical quantities of various class of solid present in earth mantles.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The author is thankful to Prof. B.R.K. Gupta for kind support to look into this problem.
